title: Why Chris Grayling isn't just a danger to cyclists but the whole UK transport system
text:

We’re a country out of control with a Government that doesn’t know what it’s doing. 
Or so it seems to me, though granted I have a more jaundiced view of Prime Minister Theresa May and her Cabinet of follies than some people who don’t live in the England I do. 
Worse than the Government not being in control is the fact that when things go wrong, pretty much every day at the moment, it eagerly blames someone else - the unions, Labour, and local councils are its targets of choice at the moment. 
This week, in an extraordinary exchange at Prime Minister’s Question Time, May told Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn to get on the phone to sort out the Southern Rail strike. Commuters stage a protest at Victoria Station, London, before marching to the Department for Transport, calling for Transport Secretary Chris Grayling to resign amid the continued disruption on Southern Railway (Photo: PA) 
Isn’t that her Government’s job? Yet Transport Secretary Chris Grayling’s initial reaction was to wash his hands of it, his second was to pour petrol on the flames by saying rail union Aslef had threatened 10 years of industrial action when they met. 
Grayling, caught on camera accidentally totalling a cyclist last week, is as much a danger to the whole of Britain’s transport system it seems. 
It might actually explain May’s comment to Corbyn. Was it actually a cry for help? Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jeremy Corbyn has a bad record with trains Share this video Watch Next 
Whatever her motivation, it comes at an interesting time for the re-nationalisation of the railways is very much a live political subject. The Tories are ideologically opposed to it as they cling like limpets to the notion that private ownership always trumps public ownership no matter what the evidence is. Yet the public are coming round to the idea - a survey last year revealed 59% support for re-nationalising the railways - even Tory voters came out for it in by 48% to 35%. 
One thing the government can’t blame on the unions is the social care crisis. In the last Parliament the Tories and the Lib Dems cut social care by £3bn, despite them knowing of an aging population with ever more complex needs. 
It allowed the then Chancellor George Osborne to go ahead with tax cuts for the wealthy while slashing local authority cash to councils who ended up carrying the political and financial responsibility for austerity. 
Today Osborne’s ‘economic plan’ has been officially binned by his successor as a spectacular failure, one of its consequences the growing social care crisis. Read More Jo Cox killing will not be the only one if poisonous post Brexit atmosphere continues 
Yet the Government last week suggested it was poorly performing councils who are at least partly to blame for the crisis in the social care sector which has led to the closure of hundreds of residential homes this year. 
This was a prelude to allowing cash strapped councils to increase council tax rates to deal with the crisis which means that, yet again, those who can least afford to pay are carrying the can for this government’s policy errors. 
If 2016 was a bad year, 2017 is not shaping up much better. Like us on Facebook
